children.name: Because you want st that sb else has
envious
children.definition: /ˈenviəs/  especiallywrittenyou feel envious when someone has something nice or special, and you wish that you had it too:
examples: thèm muốn, ganh tị , đố kị
▪ I see people who have opportunities I don’t have, and I get envious.
▪ She looks good, and enjoys the envious stares of other women.
envious of
ganh tỵ về
▪ Lewis was envious of Forney’s success.
enviously[adverb]
thèm muốn, ganh tỵ, lăm le
▪ She glanced enviously at Emma’s slim figure.

children.name: jealous
children.definition: /ˈdʒeləs/  you feel jealous when someone has something that you want, and you are annoyed that they have it and you do not:
examples: ghen tị đố kị
▪ Maybe he’s jealous because I got the job and he didn’t.
jealous of
gạnh tỵ với
▪ I guess some of the other kids are jealous of her talent.
▪ Rasputin was killed by men who were jealous of his influence with the Russian royal family.

children.name: envy (v)
children.definition: envy/ˈenvi/  to wish that you had the same abilities, possessions etc as someone else:
examples: ganh tị với ai
▪ I envied her. She looked so calm and capable.
envy somebody for something
ghen tỵ với ai đó một cái gì đó
▪ He always envied his brother for the way he made friends so easily.
envy somebody something
ghen tỵ với ai đó
▪ I envied him his freedom to do or say what he wanted.

children.name: envy (n)
children.definition: envy/ˈenvi/  the feeling you have when you want something that someone else has:
examples: sự ganh tị
▪ It was difficult to hide her envy as Jim described his new job.
green with envy
tái đi vì ghen tức, hết sức ghen tỵ
very envious
▪ Before you get green with envy, I had to do a lot of stuff that wasn’t so glamorous, too.
be the envy of somebody : làm ai ganh tị
be something that someone else would like to have
▪ The country has a low crime rate that is the envy of most other countries.

children.name: jealousy
children.definition: /ˈdʒeləsi/  a feeling of wanting something that someone else has, especially when this makes you angry or unhappy:
examples: sự ganh tị
▪ Professional jealousy can cause huge problems in the office.
jealousy of
ghen ăn tức ở
▪ On one level, the story of Snow White is about a mother’s jealousy of her daughter’s beauty and sexuality.

children.name: sour grapes
children.definition: /ˌsaʊəʳ ˈgreɪps/  spoken say this when you think that someone’s bad or angry behaviour is caused by jealousy:

children.name: kiểu nói người nào đó còn non và xanh không đáng bận tâm, không thèm chấp
examples: ▪ Brown said his rival’s comments were just sour grapes..

children.name: jealous
children.definition: /ˈdʒeləs/  angry and unhappy because you think your husband, girlfriend etc loves someone else more than they love you:
examples: ghen tuông
▪ Some parents feel jealous if their child loves the nanny or babysitter.
▪ Corwin has several female friends, and says his wife has never been jealous.
▪ Police believe the shootings may have been the work of a jealous boyfriend.
get jealous
dễ ghen tuông
become jealous
▪ My girlfriend gets jealous if I even look at another woman.
make somebody jealous
khiến ai đó ghen
▪ Trying to make your boyfriend or girlfriend jealous isn’t a good idea.
jealous of
ghen tỵ với
▪ Some fathers are jealous of the attention a new baby receives, even if they won’t admit it.
jealously[adverb]
vẻ ghen tuông
▪ He watched jealously as Rose danced with his brother.

children.name: jealousy
children.definition: /ˈdʒeləsi/  the angry, unhappy feeling you have when you think your husband, girlfriend etc loves someone else more than they love you:
examples: sự ghen tuông
▪ The police believe Morgan strangled his girlfriend in a fit of jealousy.
▪ For a moment, she was overcome by jealousy.
jealousy of
sự nghen tuông của
▪ How should a single mother deal with her son’s jealousy of her new boyfriend?

children.name: possessive
children.definition: /pəˈzesɪv/  someone who is possessive wants their husband or wife, children, friends etc to love only them, and does not like them spending time with other people:
examples: sở hữu, chiếm hữu, tỏ ý muốn chiếm hữu
▪ She was too possessive, always wanting to know where I was, who I was with.
possessive of/about
sở hữu của/về
▪ She is extremely possessive about her university friends, and doesn’t like them mixing independently with her workmates.
